awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: PerSoNet: Overlay Virtual Private Networks Spanning Personal Clouds and Social Peers
awd_abstract_narration:
Progress in mobile and cloud computing leads to an ever-increasing number of devices with increasing diversity in capacity, capabilities and usage modalities. Furthermore, the wide adoption of Online Social Networks (OSNs) for user interaction points to a future where applications increasingly demand the ability to communicate among distributed personal devices, and across those of social peers. It is crucial for these devices to communicate with each other not only seamlessly, but also securely. However, the increased number, mobility and diversity of devices pose ever-increasing challenges. Outside of an enterprise environment, users remain typically responsible for managing their own devices which is complex and error-prone. To address these challenges, this project develops PerSoNet, a novel approach based on overlay peer-to-peer (P2P) networks allowing Internet users to seamlessly establish virtual private networks connecting their own personal devices  and extending to devices of their trusted peers by leveraging OSNs as a basis for user and device discovery and for the setup of private communication channels.

PerSoNet is an unstructured P2P overlay whose topology is derived from personal device links and social networking relationships. It supports private end-to-end communication among various personal devices, leverages social relationships for the discovery and setup of private messaging channels among social peers, and applies network virtualization techniques to support unmodified software. Thus, existing and future applications can communicate privately within personal device networks and across social peers, abstracting friend connections as network links, without forfeiting the use of existing OSNs for seamless discovery and management of relationships, and exposing using well-known network abstractions and programming primitives to developers. Specifically, PerSoNet exposes a layer-2 virtual network abstraction among the set of personal devices, and a layer-3 abstraction across devices of social network users, providing a basis to support existing and future applications. The project investigates novel overlay techniques with quantitative studies, using simulation techniques and also by advancing the state-of-the-art in systems design and implementation through a software prototype and experiments with realistic applications and systems. This project has the potential to impact a large number of OSN users in applications including private data sharing, private communication among peers, and disaster- and censorship-resistant communication systems. The PerSoNet software will be available to the systems research community, open-source developers, and the public at large.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: Future Internet applications will increasingly demand interactive communication among groups of devices, including those deployed by social peers, which may be mobile, connected to different networks, and subject to different policies. This project researched a novel network overlay that embeds social and personal device links in its topology, provides virtual private networking as a core service, and effectively supports mobile peers. The resulting system researched in this project, called PerSoNet, is a communication system where every participating user device has virtual private links that establish overlay personal and social networks spanning their devices and those of Online Social Network (OSN) peers. To realize this vision, this project led to novel technical contributions in overlay bootstrapping, topology management, and programmable networking. While social graphs inherently exhibit high-degree nodes, user devices (e.g. smartphones) are often constrained in terms of processing, bandwidth, addressability, and mobility, limiting their ability to establish overlay links. PerSoNet supports existing and future applications by abstracting the overlay as a virtual network - and because its practical applicability hinges on the ability to scale and deliver acceptable performance to relevant applications, the system has been implemented and evaluated in realistic testbeds. We have investigated hybrid solutions that utilize both Software Defined Networking (SDN) switches and overlay networks to create software-defined PerSoNet virtual networks, and applications of such hybrid overlay/SDN virtual private networks in social networking, cloud and edge computing. In our proposed approach, a software-managed overlay network takes the responsibility of creating peer-to-peer virtual links, by establishing tunnels across the public Internet, even when personal devices are in different network providers and constrained by middleboxes (NATs, firewalls). The overlay network virtual links terminate in ports of SDN-controlled software switches, allowing packets sent/received by Internet-of-Things (IoT), edge and cloud computing resources that reach a switch to be forwarded across the overlay to other nodes. The resulting virtualized overlay network creates a software abstraction of an Ethernet network, and in doing so, simplifies the complexities associated with the deployment of middleware and applications across personal, edge and cloud resources. In addition, the overlay network allows dynamic membership and grouping of resources, and enforces authentication and privacy in communication, addressing key management and security concerns. The project applied PerSoNet as a basis to support an orchestration framework for instantiating on-demand edge data processing infrastructure composed of voluntary resources and data. This approach - SocialEdge - is novel in how it integrates PerSoNet networks with recursive containerization at endpoints, adapting components of a widely-used open source orchestration framework (Kubernetes) and container runtimes to: 1) confine shared resources to run only agreed upon and intended workloads; 2) enable a lightweight approach to sharing of resources at fine granularity and ensuring secure data access by nodes belonging to selected individuals chosen by data volunteers; and 3) greatly simplify the orchestration of the on-demand edge infrastructure.

 

Broader impact: In addition to research outcomes including novel approaches to effectively self-organize and route messages across overlay topologies derived from OSNs, another outcome of the project has been open-source software that integrates private network "tunnels" that can be established across the Internet with modern SDN programmable networking techniques to implement the proposed approach. The resulting open-source virtual network software has been used as a basis for collaborations with lake ecologists, who are applying virtual networks in the context of sensor-to-cloud workflows for ecological forecasting. The open-source software also provided a foundation for international collaborations seeking to apply distributed sensing, processing and data staging at the network's edge, combined with data analysis and long-term storage at the core of cloud computing infrastructures. The project has provided opportunities for training and professional development of graduate students and several undergraduate and high school interns.
